{
  "overview": "The purpose of this Act is to make the women's court pilot program in the first circuit permanent. [CHUNK_6] It also establishes a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the third circuit. [CHUNK_6] Additionally, the Act requires the judiciary to submit a report to the legislature regarding the need for and the associated costs of a pilot program for women's court in the second and fifth circuits and Hilo division of the third circuit. [CHUNK_8]",
  "appropriations": "There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $514,900 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027. [CHUNK_17] These funds are for mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services, and the establishment of two temporary positions. [CHUNK_18] The sums appropriated shall be expended by the judiciary for the purposes of this Act. [CHUNK_19]",
  "assumptions_and_methodology": "The provided documents do not specify the assumptions or methodology used to determine the appropriation amounts. [CHUNK_17] However, the Committee on Judiciary finds that closing the service gap for the most at-risk women in the Kona area of the Third District is imperative, based on data and information provided by the Judiciary in testimony at the public hearing on this measure. [CHUNK_36] The committee also notes the Third Circuit is at a disadvantage to address crime motivators due to limited community resources, funding, and geographic restrictions. [CHUNK_33]",
  "agency_impact": "The Judiciary will be responsible for making the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent. [CHUNK_22] The Judiciary will also establish the women's court pilot program within the third circuit Kona division, which will be under the supervision of the big island drug court. [CHUNK_10] The Judiciary is also required to submit multiple reports to the legislature regarding the new pilot program and the need for programs in other circuits. [CHUNK_13, CHUNK_20]",
  "economic_impact": "This measure aims to support women dealing with trauma, abuse, and unhealthy relationships by providing substance abuse treatment and mental health support. [CHUNK_36, CHUNK_37] The pilot program's goal is to divert participants from incarceration, support their success in the community, and reduce recidivism. [CHUNK_11] This addresses issues in Hawaii County, which has the highest poverty rate in the State, high rates of domestic violence, and limited opportunities for employment, all of which disproportionately impact women. [CHUNK_34]",
  "policy_impact": "This Act makes the women's court pilot program in the first circuit permanent by amending Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, to remove its repeal date. [CHUNK_9] It establishes a new temporary three-year Women's Court Pilot Program within the Kona division of the Third Circuit. [CHUNK_22] The measure also shifts the focus from a previously proposed interim study for the Third Circuit to requiring a report on the need for pilot programs in the Second and Fifth Circuits and the Hilo division of the Third Circuit. [CHUNK_41, CHUNK_42]",
  "revenue_sources": "The bill appropriates funds out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [CHUNK_17] The sums appropriated are $514,900 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027. [CHUNK_17] No other revenue sources are identified in the provided documents. [CHUNK_17]",
  "six_year_fiscal_implications": "The measure appropriates $514,900 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027 for the Kona pilot program. [CHUNK_17] The Kona pilot program is established as a three-year program, suggesting a third year of funding will be required for fiscal year 2027-2028, though no amount is specified. [CHUNK_22] The Kona pilot program is repealed on June 30, 2028. [CHUNK_22] The bill also makes the women's court pilot program in the first circuit permanent, implying ongoing fiscal obligations that are not funded by this measure. [CHUNK_6] The judiciary is required to submit a report to the legislature prior to the 2026 regular session regarding the need for and associated costs of a pilot program in other circuits. [CHUNK_20] Additionally, the judiciary must submit reports in 2026, 2027, and 2028 on the status of the Kona pilot program, including recommendations on whether it should continue or be expanded. [CHUNK_14, CHUNK_16] These reports will inform future fiscal implications. [CHUNK_16]",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "The provided legislative documents do not indicate any anticipated impact on operating revenues. [CHUNK_17]",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "The provided legislative documents do not specify any capital expenditures. [CHUNK_18] The appropriations are designated for mental health, substance abuse treatment, other services, and the establishment of two temporary positions. [CHUNK_18] No funds are allocated for facilities or major equipment. [CHUNK_18]",
  "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "The Kona pilot program established in Part III of the act is repealed on June 30, 2028, ending its fiscal obligations. [CHUNK_22] However, the bill makes the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent, which will result in ongoing fiscal implications beyond the six-year period. [CHUNK_22] The costs associated with the permanent program are not specified in this measure. [CHUNK_6]",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "The current version of the bill significantly changes the scope and funding from the previous version. [CHUNK_38] The pilot program is now established in the Kona division of the Third Circuit, rather than the Second and Fifth Circuits as previously proposed. [CHUNK_38] Unlike the previous version which had unspecified appropriations, this measure inserts specific amounts of $514,900 (HB727_SD1_SSCR1240_.htm.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_SD1_SSCR1240_.htm.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027. [CHUNK_39] This version also adds two temporary FTE positions for the Judiciary, whereas the previous version had no FTEs and considered unspecified positions for the Department of Health. [CHUNK_18, CHUNK_40] The requirement for an interim study to establish a blueprint for a program in the Third Circuit was deleted, and a new reporting requirement was added for a needs assessment for other circuits. [CHUNK_41, CHUNK_42]",
  "fte_positions": "This measure includes funding for the establishment of two temporary positions. [CHUNK_18] The positions are one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) Kona drug court probation supervisor position and one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) peer specialist position. [CHUNK_18] This is a change from a previous version, which deleted language that would have appropriated funds for an unspecified number of temporary positions for the Department of Health. [CHUNK_40]",
  "appropriations_changes": "Appropriations were previously unspecified. [CHUNK_40] Your Committee has amended this measure by inserting an appropriation amount of $514,900 (HB727_SD1_SSCR1240_.htm.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_SD1_SSCR1240_.htm.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027. [CHUNK_39] These funds are specified for services and two temporary positions for the Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit. [CHUNK_39]",
  "funding_sources_changes": "The funding source for the appropriation is the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [CHUNK_17] While the previous fiscal note indicated the funding mechanism was unchanged, this version explicitly appropriates funds from the general fund. [CHUNK_17] No other funding sources are mentioned. [CHUNK_17]",
  "department_impact": "This version of the bill specifies that the sums appropriated shall be expended by the judiciary. [CHUNK_19] This is a change from a previous version, which included language that would have appropriated an unspecified amount of funds to the Department of Health. [CHUNK_40] The language appropriating funds to the Department of Health has been deleted. [CHUNK_40]",
  "reports_required": "The bill requires the judiciary to submit a report to the legislature no later than forty days prior to the convening of the regular session of 2026 regarding the need for and the associated costs of a pilot program for women's court in the second and fifth circuits and Hilo division of the third circuit. [CHUNK_20] Additionally, the judiciary must submit annual reports to the governor and legislature prior to the regular sessions of 2026, 2027, and 2028 on the status of the Kona pilot program. [CHUNK_14] The previous requirement for the Third Circuit to conduct an interim study to establish a blueprint was deleted. [CHUNK_41]",
  "pilot_program": "This measure establishes a three-year Women's Court Pilot Program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the Third Circuit, rather than the Second and Fifth Circuits as previously proposed. [CHUNK_38] This pilot program shall be under the supervision of the big island drug court. [CHUNK_10] The bill also makes the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent. [CHUNK_37]",
  "sunset_date": "Part III of this Act, which establishes the Kona pilot program, shall be repealed on June 30, 2028. [CHUNK_22] The bill also removes the June 30, 2025 repeal date for the First Circuit's pilot program, making it permanent. [CHUNK_9]",
  "effective_date": "This Act shall take effect on April 23, 2057. [CHUNK_22] This effective date was inserted to encourage further discussion. [CHUNK_43]"
}

PART I SECTION 1. The legislature finds that there has been a significant increase in the number of women in Hawai ʻ i jails and prisons over the past forty years, resulting in a higher proportion of women who are incarcerated. Research reflects that for women, histories of abuse, trauma,

incarcerated. Research reflects that for women, histories of abuse, trauma, poverty, mental illness, substance use disorders, and unhealthy relationships intersect with their entry into criminal behavior. Women offenders also face unique barriers to success after incarceration. They are more likely to be primary caregivers for young children, have lower educational

to be primary caregivers for young children, have lower educational attainment, lack stable work history, and experience economic or social marginalization, which prevents them from having more positive outcomes. The legislature further finds that Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, established a three-year women's court pilot program in the

2022, established a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the first circuit. This program, known as Mohala Wahine, focuses on non-violent women who are at high risk of recidivism and in need of multiple services such as substance abuse treatment, therapy, or housing. The program began

as substance abuse treatment, therapy, or housing. The program began accepting participants in January 2023, with a goal of admitting twenty women each year. As of August 2024, twenty-three women are currently participating in the program, with eleven participants in phase one of treatment and twelve participants in phase two

phase one of treatment and twelve participants in phase two of treatment. The purpose of this Act is to: (1) Make the women's court pilot program in the first circuit permanent; (2) Establish a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the third

the circuit court of the Kona division of the third circuit, which is intended to acknowledge the distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system and address their individualized needs; and (3) Require the judiciary to submit a report to the legislature regarding the need for and the

report to the legislature regarding the need for and the associated costs of a pilot program for women's court in the second and fifth circuits and Hilo division of the third circuit. PART II SECTION 2. Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, is amended by amending section 5 to

of Hawaii 2022, is amended by amending section 5 to read as follows: "SECTION 5. This Act shall take effect on July 1, 2022[ , and shall be repealed on June 30, 2025 ]." PART III SECTION 3. (a) There shall be established within the third circuit Kona division of

shall be established within the third circuit Kona division of the judiciary the women's court pilot program. The women's court pilot program shall be under the supervision of the big island drug court. The pilot program shall implement trauma-informed and evidence-based practices, employ gender-responsive programming, collaborate with stakeholders, and provide

evidence-based practices, employ gender-responsive programming, collaborate with stakeholders, and provide services to women in the court system with the goal of diverting participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism. (b) The services offered by the pilot program shall address the following areas: (1) Trauma and

pilot program shall address the following areas: (1) Trauma and mental health treatment; (2) Family support, including parenting, education, and relationship improvement; (3) Life-skills training; (4) Education and vocational training; (5) Domestic violence prevention; (6) Medical services and health education; (7) Substance abuse detection, prevention, and treatment; (8) Mentoring; and

SSCR1240 STAND. COM. REP. NO. 1240 Honolulu, Hawaii RE: H.B. No. 727 H.D. 1 S.D. 1 Honorable Ronald D. Kouchi President of the Senate Thirty-Third State Legislature Regular Session of 2025 State of Hawaii Sir: Your Committee on Judiciary, to which was referred H.B. No. 727, H.D. 1, entitled: "A

which was referred H.B. No. 727, H.D. 1, entitled: "A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO THE WOMEN'S COURT," begs leave to report as follows: The purpose and intent of this measure is to: (1) Establish a three—year Women's Court Pilot Program in the circuit court of the Second and

Pilot Program in the circuit court of the Second and Fifth Circuits, which is intended to acknowledge the distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system and address their individualized needs; and (2) Require the Third Circuit of the Judiciary and Big Island Drug Court to conduct an

the Judiciary and Big Island Drug Court to conduct an interim study to establish a blueprint for a Women's Court Pilot Program in the Third Circuit. Your Committee received testimony in support of this measure from the Judiciary, Department of Health, Office of the Public Defender, State Council on Mental

Health, Office of the Public Defender, State Council on Mental Health, Department of the Prosecuting Attorney of the County of Maui, Office of the Prosecuting Attorney of the County of Hawai ʻ i, County of Hawai ʻ i Committee on the Status of Women, Hawaii Substance Abuse Coalition, West Hawaii

the Status of Women, Hawaii Substance Abuse Coalition, West Hawaii Bar Association, Community Alliance on Prisons, and nine individuals. Your Committee finds that Mohala Wahine, or the State's Women's Court three-year pilot program, was established in the First Circuit by Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, and has been

Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, and has been operational since January 2023. The mission of Mohala Wahine is to assist and guide participants in meeting their legal and statutory responsibilities and to facilitate change in the participants' well-being by providing gender-responsive services that uphold the mission of the

by providing gender-responsive services that uphold the mission of the State's Judiciary and the Adult Client Services Branch. Additionally, Mohala Wahine aims to enhance community safety by reducing recidivism through evidence-based, trauma-informed care, and cultural practices. Your Committee further finds that thus far, the Women's Court Pilot Program has been

that thus far, the Women's Court Pilot Program has been successful, with eleven participants in phase one of treatment and twelve participants in phase two of treatment. Given the success of the First District's Mohala Wahine, your Committee believes that the Mohala Wahine Pilot Program should become permanent. Your Committee

the Mohala Wahine Pilot Program should become permanent. Your Committee additionally finds that the Third Circuit, specifically the Kona area, is at a disadvantage to address crime motivators such as substance abuse, mental health, and homelessness, given its limited community resources and funding, geographic restrictions, limitations of court supervision authorities,

resources and funding, geographic restrictions, limitations of court supervision authorities, overcrowded correctional facilities, understaffed law enforcement, and shortage of direct service providers. Additionally, Hawaii County has the highest poverty rate in the State, high rates of domestic violence, and limited opportunities for employment, all of which disproportionately impact women, who

opportunities for employment, all of which disproportionately impact women, who are more likely to be victims of violence and more likely to have dependent children in their care. Your Committee believes that, based on data and information provided by the Judiciary in testimony at the public hearing on this measure,

Judiciary in testimony at the public hearing on this measure, closing the service gap for the most at-risk women in the Kona area of the Third District is imperative. This measure will support women in the State dealing with trauma, abuse, unhealthy relationships, and more by providing substance abuse treatment,

abuse, unhealthy relationships, and more by providing substance abuse treatment, mental health support, and assistance with navigating the criminal and social services systems. Accordingly, your Committee has amended this measure by: (1) Inserting language making the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent; (2) Establishing a three—year Women's

in the First Circuit permanent; (2) Establishing a three—year Women's Court Pilot Program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the Third Circuit, rather than the Second and Fifth Circuits; (3) Specifying that the Women's Court Pilot Program is under the supervision of the Big Island Drug Court;

is under the supervision of the Big Island Drug Court; (4) Inserting an appropriation amount of $514,900 for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 for fiscal year 2026-2027 for services and two temporary positions for the Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit; (5) Deleting language

later than forty days prior to the Regular Session of 2026 regarding the need for and the associated costs of a pilot program for Women's Court in the Second and Firth Circuits and Hilo division of the Third Circuit; (8) Amending section 1 to reflect its amended purpose; (9) Inserting

overview.prompt: Using the provided legislative documents, statutes, and testimonies, write a clear summary describing the purpose, scope, and key components of the proposed measure or bill, including any pilot or permanent programs, reporting requirements, and sunset clauses. This should be around 3 sentences.
overview.description: General overview and summary of the measure

appropriations.prompt: Based on budgetary data and legislative appropriations, detail the funding allocated for the program or measure, including fiscal years, amounts, intended uses such as staffing, training, contracts, technology, etc... This should be around 3 sentences.

assumptions_and_methodology.prompt: Explain the assumptions, cost estimation methods, and data sources used to calculate the financial projections for this program or measure, referencing comparable programs or historical budgets where applicable. This should be around 3 sentences.

agency_impact.prompt: Describe the anticipated operational, administrative, and budgetary impact of the program or measure on the relevant government agency or department, including supervision, staffing, and resource allocation. This should be around 3 sentences.
agency_impact.description: Impact on government agencies and departments

economic_impact.prompt: Summarize the expected economic effects of the program or measure, such as cost savings, potential reductions in related expenditures, benefits to the community, and any relevant performance or participation statistics. This should be around 3 sentences.

policy_impact.prompt: Analyze the policy implications of the measure, including how it modifies existing laws or programs, its role within broader legislative strategies, and its potential effects on state or local governance. This should be around 3 sentences.

revenue_sources.prompt: Identify and describe the funding sources that will support the program or measure, such as general funds, grants, fees, or other revenue streams, based on the provided fiscal documents. This should be around 3 sentences.

six_year_fiscal_implications.prompt: Provide a multi-year fiscal outlook (e.g., six years) for the program or measure, projecting costs, staffing changes, recurring expenses, and assumptions about program expansion or permanence using available budget and workload data. This should be around 10 sentences.

operating_revenue_impact.prompt: Describe any anticipated impacts on operating revenues resulting from the program or measure, including increases, decreases, or changes in revenue streams. This should be around 3 sentences.

capital_expenditure_impact.prompt: Outline any expected capital expenditures related to the program or measure, such as investments in facilities, equipment, or technology infrastructure, based on capital budgets or agency plans. This should be around 3 sentences.

fiscal_implications_after_6_years.prompt: Summarize the ongoing fiscal obligations after the initial multi-year period for the program or measure, including annual operating costs, expected number of program sites or units, and the sustainability of funding. This should be around 3 sentences.
fiscal_implications_after_6_years.description: Long-term fiscal obligations beyond six years

updates_from_previous_fiscal_note.prompt: If you are given a previous fiscal note. Please summarize the MAIN POINTS that are different from the previous fiscal note and the new fiscal note.

fte_positions.prompt: Detail any Full Time Equivalent (FTE) positions that have been added or modified in this version of the bill, including the number of positions, their roles, and any changes from previous versions. This should be around 3 sentences.

appropriations_changes.prompt: Identify and describe any appropriations that were previously unspecified or have been modified between versions of the bill, including the amounts and purposes of the appropriations. This should be around 3 sentences.
appropriations_changes.description: Changes to appropriations between bill versions

funding_sources_changes.prompt: Specify the method of funding (MOF) for appropriations and identify any changes in funding sources between versions, such as shifts between general fund and special fund appropriations. This should be around 3 sentences.
funding_sources_changes.description: Changes to funding sources and method of funding

department_impact.prompt: Describe any changes in which department is responsible for expending appropriations, including shifts from one department to another between bill versions (e.g., from Department of Health to Judiciary). This should be around 3 sentences.
department_impact.description: Changes in department responsibility for appropriations

reports_required.prompt: Identify any reports that agencies are required to submit to the legislature, including new reporting requirements or modifications to existing ones. This should be around 3 sentences.

pilot_program.prompt: If the bill creates a pilot program, describe the length of the pilot program and whether it was initially intended to be a pilot program or a permanent program. This should be around 3 sentences.

sunset_date.prompt: Identify the sunset date for the bill or program, including any modifications to the sunset date between versions. This should be around 2 sentences.

effective_date.prompt: Identify the effective date of the bill, noting if there was a defective effective date in a previous version and what the corrected effective date is. This should be around 2 sentences.

Women offenders also face unique barriers to success after incarceration. They are more likely to be primary caregivers for young children, have lower educational

to be primary caregivers for young children, have lower educational attainment, lack stable work history, and experience economic or social marginalization, which prevents them from having more positive outcomes. The legislature further finds that Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, established a three-year women's court pilot program in the

2022, established a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the first circuit. This program, known as Mohala Wahine, focuses on non-violent women who are at high risk of recidivism and in need of multiple services such as substance abuse treatment, therapy, or housing. The program began

as substance abuse treatment, therapy, or housing. The program began accepting participants in January 2023, with a goal of admitting twenty women each year. SSCR1240 STAND. COM. REP. NO. 1240 Honolulu, Hawaii RE: H.B. No. 727 H.D. 1 S.D. 1 Honorable Ronald D. Kouchi President of the Senate Thirty-Third State Legislature Regular Session of 2025 State of Hawaii Sir: Your Committee on Judiciary, to which was referred H.B. No. 727, H.D. 1, entitled: "A

which was referred H.B. No. 727, H.D. 1, entitled: "A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO THE WOMEN'S COURT," begs leave to report as follows: The purpose and intent of this measure is to: (1) Establish a three—year Women's Court Pilot Program in the circuit court of the Second and

Pilot Program in the circuit court of the Second and Fifth Circuits, which is intended to acknowledge the distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system and address their individualized needs; and (2) Require the Third Circuit of the Judiciary and Big Island Drug Court to conduct an

the Judiciary and Big Island Drug Court to conduct an interim study to establish a blueprint for a Women's Court Pilot Program in the Third Circuit. Your Committee received testimony in support of this measure from the Judiciary, Department of Health, Office of the Public Defender, State Council on Mental

Health, Office of the Public Defender, State Council on Mental Health, Department of the Prosecuting Attorney of the County of Maui, Office of the Prosecuting Attorney of the County of Hawai ʻ i, County of Hawai ʻ i Committee on the Status of Women, Hawaii Substance Abuse Coalition, West Hawaii

the Status of Women, Hawaii Substance Abuse Coalition, West Hawaii Bar Association, Community Alliance on Prisons, and nine individuals. Your Committee finds that Mohala Wahine, or the State's Women's Court three-year pilot program, was established in the First Circuit by Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, and has been

Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, and has been operational since January 2023. The mission of Mohala Wahine is to assist and guide participants in meeting their legal and statutory responsibilities and to facilitate change in the participants' well-being by providing gender-responsive services that uphold the mission of the

by providing gender-responsive services that uphold the mission of the State's Judiciary and the Adult Client Services Branch. Additionally, Mohala Wahine aims to enhance community safety by reducing recidivism through evidence-based, trauma-informed care, and cultural practices. Your Committee further finds that thus far, the Women's Court Pilot Program has been

that thus far, the Women's Court Pilot Program has been successful, with eleven participants in phase one of treatment and twelve participants in phase two of treatment. Given the success of the First District's Mohala Wahine, your Committee believes that the Mohala Wahine Pilot Program should become permanent. Your Committee

the Mohala Wahine Pilot Program should become permanent. Your Committee additionally finds that the Third Circuit, specifically the Kona area, is at a disadvantage to address crime motivators such as substance abuse, mental health, and homelessness, given its limited community resources and funding, geographic restrictions, limitations of court supervision authorities,

resources and funding, geographic restrictions, limitations of court supervision authorities, overcrowded correctional facilities, understaffed law enforcement, and shortage of direct service providers. Additionally, Hawaii County has the highest poverty rate in the State, high rates of domestic violence, and limited opportunities for employment, all of which disproportionately impact women, who

opportunities for employment, all of which disproportionately impact women, who are more likely to be victims of violence and more likely to have dependent children in their care. Your Committee believes that, based on data and information provided by the Judiciary in testimony at the public hearing on this measure,

Judiciary in testimony at the public hearing on this measure, closing the service gap for the most at-risk women in the Kona area of the Third District is imperative. This measure will support women in the State dealing with trauma, abuse, unhealthy relationships, and more by providing substance abuse treatment,

abuse, unhealthy relationships, and more by providing substance abuse treatment, mental health support, and assistance with navigating the criminal and social services systems.
